paper_abstract: In this paper, we study some average properties of hypergraphs and the average complexity of algorithms applied to hypergraphs under different probabilistic models. Our approach is both theoretical and experimental since our goal is to obtain a random model that is able to capture the real-data complexity. Starting from a model that generalizes the Erdos-Renyi model [10,11], we obtain asymptotic estimations on the average number of transversals, irredundants and minimal transversals in a random hypergraph. We use those results to obtain an upper bound on the average complexity of algorithms to generate the minimal transversals of a hypergraph. Then we make our random model more complex in order to bring it closer to real-data and identify cases where the average number of minimal transversals is at most polynomial, quasi-polynomial or exponential. (C) 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: An average study of hypergraphs and their minimal transversals
